page.title: 04Buckhead 1984/5 N.U.M.Strike
page.content: The miners strike 1984/5 affected the Buckhead Opencast Site.It was originally intended that all coal produced on the site would be taken to the N.C.B. Disposal Plant at Swalwell on Tyneside to be sorted and crushed to a maximum size of 2" before being transported to the power stations.The strike stopped the transporting of the coal from the site, but did not affect the actual mining.Thus large stock piles of coal formed.This caused two great problems i.e.danger of combustion and possibility of pollution.The untreated, stacked coal gave off an acidic/iron orange liquid which had to be drained into deep lagoons and neutralised by lime to avoid the pollution of nearby streams. The piles had to be compressed to keep out hot air to minimise the risk of combustion.(continued)
